DataElement.preferredName: Gene Expression Level Immunohistochemistry Staining Method Finding Stain Pattern DistributionOfStain
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.:A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.:Immunohistochemical staining techniques allow for the visualization of antigens via the sequential application of a specific antibody to the antigen (primary antibody), a secondary antibody to the primary antibody and an enzyme complex with a chromogenic substrate. The enzymatic activation of the chromogen results in a visible reaction product at the antigen site. The specimen may then be counterstained and coverslipped. Results are interpreted using a light microscope and aid in the differential diagnosis of pathophysiological processes, which may or may not be associated with a particular antigen.:Objective evidence of disease perceptible to the examining physician (sign) and subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient (symptom)._A dye or other coloring material that is used in microscopy to make structures visible.:A distinctive style or form of something, the characteristic set of traits or actions or qualities of a group, person, or thing, as behavior patterns; in molecular biology: a nucleic acid or protein motif that is computationally detectable within aligned sequences._Indicates the way how the stain is distributed,

ObjectClass.preferredName: Gene Expression Level Immunohistochemistry Staining Method Finding
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.:A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.:Immunohistochemical staining techniques allow for the visualization of antigens via the sequential application of a specific antibody to the antigen (primary antibody), a secondary antibody to the primary antibody and an enzyme complex with a chromogenic substrate. Concepts.definition: Typically involves transcription of genetically encoded information into an intermediary message (messenger RNA) and subsequent translation into a functional protein.
A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

Immunohistochemical staining techniques allow for the visualization of antigens via the sequential application of a specific antibody to the antigen (primary antibody), a secondary antibody to the primary antibody and an enzyme complex with a chromogenic substrate. The enzymatic activation of the chromogen results in a visible reaction product at the antigen site. The specimen may then be counterstained and coverslipped. Results are interpreted using a light microscope and aid in the differential diagnosis of pathophysiological processes, which may or may not be associated with a particular antigen.
Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

Property.preferredDefinition: A dye or other coloring material that is used in microscopy to make structures visible.:A distinctive style or form of something, the characteristic set of traits or actions or qualities of a group, person, or thing, as behavior patterns; in molecular biology: a nucleic acid or protein motif that is computationally detectable within aligned sequences.

Concepts.definition: A dye or other coloring material that is used in microscopy to make structures visible.
An arrangement of objects, facts, behaviors, or other things which have scientific, mathematical, geometric, statistical, or other meaning.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Indicates the way how the stain is distributed,_Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The quality or state of consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature.

Concepts.definition: The quality or state of consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The quality or state of being similar or comparable in kind or nature or of being uniform throughout in composition or structure.

Concepts.definition: The quality or state of being similar or comparable in kind or nature or of being uniform throughout in composition or structure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Arising from or pertaining to many locations.

Concepts.definition: Arising from, pertaining to, or having many locations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Arising from, pertaining to, or having a single location.

Concepts.definition: Arising from, pertaining to, or having a single location.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Representation term 'Type' added per request of loading team to suport SIW requirements on 7/31/2008
